Award.AwardTitle: The Application of Genome-wide Association Studies to Behavioral Traits

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is 3-year ethnographic study of the emerging field of social science genetics which pairs genome-wide association and structural DNA analysis with social research to find genomic causes for non-disease social phenomena such as educational attainment, promiscuity, gang behavior, and debt. Such research is being led by scientists new to genomics, yet dedicated to revolutionizing its foundational theories and methods so that social outcomes can be linked to genetic traits. Already judges, state officials, and preschool administrators have implemented techniques from this emerging field to test criminals and prospective students for pro and antisocial traits. Despite the science's growing impact on the broader landscape of science, public health, and public discourses and practices, no studies have yet analyzed this emerging field.


This project will facilitate more fruitful collaborations between the natural and social sciences, and the public in order to promote and sustain our national health. Upon completion of the study, the PI expects to be equipped to recommend more efficacious and socially responsible genetic and social science research ethics. The PI will ensure the impact of this research by circulating recommendations for best practices of multidisciplinary research to study institutions, funding agencies, researchers, and universities that are not only trying to foster inter- and transdisciplinary research within academic arenas but also across university-industry ties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Do your genes say that you were born to get a PhD or a life sentence in prison? Are you genetically predisposed to entrepreneurship or credit card debt? Does your DNA make you vote liberal or conservative? Are you innately bent toward marriage or bachelor life? These are some of the burning questions that the new genetic science of behavior, social genomics, attempts to address.

Social genomics emerged only a decade ago. Yet, the science has quickly gained ground in public health and the public sphere with a battery of study publications and media blitzes arguing for genetic influences for an array of social phenomena. Newspapers have reported experts considering the use of research findings for education, child welfare, and criminal justice. Meanwhile, growing constellations of funders in health, justice, and public administration have come forward to support the science in its newest efforts to find genetic determinants of behavior.

This research examined the science and its public, the researchers and the everyday people affected by their work, in an effort to understand the power and influence of genetics over science and society today. It traced the field’s emergence in the Decade of the Genome, and its rapid rise to fame as a trifecta of genoeconomics, genopolitics, and genosociology. It mapped the science’s social science roots, its central conceptual and methodological motivations, and analyzed the meaning its interdisciplinary structure has had for the natural, social, and health sciences. Finally, it assessed its impact on public notions of human difference, especially around race, gender, and sexuality.

This research found that a new unique and autonomous field of research has formed, one that has rapidly institutionalized within the broader scientific community and gained public notoriety for its message about the gene-environment roots of all aspects of life. This is a truly transdisciplinary field that is innovatively melding social and natural science approaches and practices, and is building bridges within the social and natural sciences across their normally distinct home disciplines. However, the field produces a form of “imbalanced interdisciplinarity,” in that it prioritizes the search for genetic causes of social phenomena, often leaving rigorous explanations of the environment aside. As a result, behaviors are geneticized, cast as genetic in reductionist terms. Furthermore, the sciences, especially the social sciences are molecularized as genetic models encroach upon a range of previously nongenetic, environment-focused fields.

This research also found that despite the wealth of expertise many social genomics practitioners possess about the constructionist nature of our major axes of human difference, this field characterizes differences like race, gender, and sexuality as essential biology. Race is conceived as a matter of genetic population divergence, something to be controlled for in studies. Gender is conflated with sex, also treated as something to be controlled for methodologically. Sexuality is seen as a biological fact, though practitioners do question its basis when it comes to sexual orientation. The danger in these characterizations is in traits coming across as property of a particular group, mutually exclusive of others.

Today, a new eugenics is unfolding, as practitioners and expert proponents further afield argue for the use of research in shaping policy in ways that target social and health policy toward genetic profiles. They envision a host of social institutions using genetic data to ensure a person’s educational or occupational success. It remains to be seen how this approach will dovetail with emerging human gene editing technologies that may be targeted toward social behavior, and how stratified groups will differentially access and avail themselves of policies or technologies.

This research has been disseminated through international and domestic lectures in an array of academic, biomedical, and public health venues, as well as major media broadcasts, interviews, and publications. The results of this research have been published as a book titled Social by Nature: The Promise and Peril of Sociogenomics.
